Martin, however, does not particularly enjoy their company and only interacts with them when necessary to avoid rudeness. He suspects that his presence makes them uncomfortable.

As more cousins join them on the yacht for the ocean voyage, Martin becomes increasingly isolated. Despite the presence of his cousins, he spends the rest of his life on "The Interregnum" and feels safer from Conrad, a threat from his own time. The cousins' impact on Martin's life is one of isolation and disconnection, as he is unable to form meaningful connections with them and feels alienated from his own time and society.

In the story "The Man Outside," time plays a significant role in the protagonist's journey and has consequences when manipulated. The protagonist, Michaelson, feeling depressed and alone, finds solace on a desert knoll outside the city. He buries the body of an old native there, but he becomes aware that the old man's body and spirit are somehow disassociated beyond death.

Michaelson becomes fascinated with a clock-like instrument that the old man possessed. He spends weeks learning the language and searching for information about the instrument in books. Eventually, he decides to test the machine himself and presses the button, resulting in a high-pitched whine and a sense of void and darkness.

He finds himself in a place with no direction, where the old man's thoughts reach him. The old man informs Michaelson that he can be anywhere and see anywhere on the planet, even on Earth. However, the old man warns him that no one can go back in time, which disappoints Michaelson. Despite this, he decides to try anyway.

In another part of the story, a man named Ronald is trapped in the File Room by Manet, the protagonist of this section. Manet contemplates the concept of time as he listens to a transmission from Earth, which discusses the estimated time it will take to complete the atmosphere seeding project on Mars. The estimate has changed over the years, causing Manet to reflect on the flat 18 years he will have to spend on Mars.

Manet remembers a box he has that contains a Modifier, a device that can change or shut off someone. He contemplates using it on Ronald, but he is unsure of its appearance without the Master Chart. He worries about Ronald being trapped for 18 years and considers the potential consequences.

In summary, time plays a significant role in "The Man Outside" as the protagonist explores the possibilities of time travel and the consequences of manipulating time. The story highlights the limitations and frustrations of trying to change the past or escape the passage of time, ultimately leading to a sense of longing and reflection on the passage of time.

Throughout "The Man Outside," Martin's opinion of his cousins does change. At first, he is skeptical of Ninian's claim that she is his great-great-grand-daughter and doesn't understand why she is trying to protect him from Conrad. He sees her as crazy and acts out by baiting her. However, as time goes on, Martin begins to understand his descendants better and even becomes skilled at understanding them. He forms a closer bond with cousin Ives, who treats him as an individual and takes his responsibilities seriously. Martin enjoys their time together and appreciates Ives' efforts to help him succeed in his art career. 

However, Martin doesn't have a strong connection with the rest of his cousins. He doesn't care much for their company and they don't seem to seek out his company either. He suspects that he makes them feel uncomfortable. Martin spends most of his life on the yacht, "The Interregnum," where he feels safer from Conrad. Despite being surrounded by his cousins, Martin remains somewhat isolated from them.

In the end, it is Ninian who cries when it is time for them to part. Martin understands that her tears are not of sorrow, but of her own inadequacy. He becomes skilled at understanding his descendants, but they never truly try to understand him. This lack of connection and understanding contributes to Martin's changing opinion of his cousins throughout the story.

The story "Spawning Ground" revolves around Captain Gwayne and his crew aboard the starship Pandora. They are on a mission to explore a distant planet, two hundred light years away from Earth, in hopes of finding a potential colony for humanity's survival.

Upon landing on the planet, the crew encounters peculiar creatures called "blobs," which appear to be sentient and have the ability to adapt and change the cells of living beings. The blobs seem to be amused by humans and have already changed the local animal life, which previously had twelve legs, to adapt to their environment.

Captain Gwayne and his crew realize that they too have been changed by the blobs, and Earth food would eventually become deadly to them. They come to the conclusion that they must stay on the planet, burying their ships deeper to avoid detection from Earth. They understand that their children, who mature in eight years, will become primitive savages in three generations, but it is necessary for the survival of the new race.

The crew acknowledges that Earth needs a place to plant its seed and preserve its bloodlines, and this alien world, with the help of the blobs, can provide that. They understand that they are needed to start the new race with a better chance of survival. They decide to stay on the planet, accepting their fate and the responsibility of replenishing the stars.

In the end, Captain Gwayne and his crew embrace their role in the new race's development, believing that their children will eventually find a way back to the starlanes and continue exploring and colonizing other worlds in the universe.

In the story "Spawning Ground," Hennessy is a captain who has undergone significant changes after encountering alien creatures known as the blobs. Initially, Captain Gwayne is skeptical of Hennessy's identity, but after Hennessy answers personal questions correctly, Gwayne begins to believe that it is indeed him. Hennessy's ability to speak English has been altered due to the changes the blobs have made to his vocal cords.

As the story progresses, it is revealed that the blobs have the power to change human cells and adapt them to the alien world. The crew members of the ship they are on have also been affected by these changes. Gwayne realizes that they cannot return to Earth as they are no longer compatible with Earth's environment and food. They decide to stay on the alien world, burying their ships deeper to hide from Earth and start a new civilization.

Gwayne explains to Jane, his companion, that they are needed on the alien world to provide a diverse set of bloodlines for the new race that will emerge. They believe that their children, who mature rapidly in just eight years, will have the ability to adapt to different worlds and continue exploring the universe. They see the entire universe as a potential spawning ground for the children of humanity.

In a separate part of the story, Ben, another character, encounters a man named Cobb who despises spacemen. This encounter leads to a confrontation between Ben and Cobb, resulting in Cobb's death. Ben is haunted by the memory of this incident, as he cannot escape the image of Cobb's lifeless body.

In summary, Hennessy undergoes physical changes due to the influence of the blobs, Gwayne and his crew decide to stay on the alien world to start a new civilization, and Ben is haunted by the memory of killing Cobb.

Jane Corey is a lieutenant on the starship Pandora. She is responsible for monitoring the activities on the planet they have landed on. In the story "Spawning Ground," Jane plays a crucial role in understanding the nature of the blobs and their effect on the human crew. She is the one who realizes that the crew members have not been fully changed by the blobs and that they can still go back to Earth. However, she also understands the importance of staying on the planet to ensure the survival of the new race that will be born there. Jane supports Captain Gwayne's decision to stay and help the new race develop and adapt to the alien world. She recognizes the potential for the children of the crew to become the future pioneers of space exploration, spreading humanity's seed throughout the universe.

In the story "Spawning Ground," the harmless insect-like creatures called blobs play a significant role in the decision of Captain Hennessy and Gwayne to stay on the planet. These blobs have adaptable cells and have been observed changing the cells of humans, adapting them to the alien world. Before humans arrived, all life on the planet had twelve legs, but the blobs have been changing that. The blobs seem to be amused by humans and do not require anything from them, but they like having humans around.

Gwayne realizes that the changes the blobs are making to humans will eventually make them unable to survive on Earth, as Earth food would kill them. Therefore, they decide to stay on the planet and hide the ships so that Earth won't find them. They believe that their presence is needed on the planet to provide a rich set of bloodlines for the new race that will emerge. They see themselves as starting a new civilization on this alien world, with the help of the blobs.

The decision to stay on the planet is also influenced by the fact that Earth needs a place to plant its seed, and this planet, with the help of the blobs, can preserve that seed for generations. Gwayne believes that their children, who mature in just eight years, will be able to grow, develop, and eventually explore other worlds with the help of the blobs. They see the whole universe as a potential spawning ground for the new race of humans.

In summary, the blobs play a crucial role in the decision to stay on the planet, as they have the ability to adapt humans to the alien world and provide a chance for the new race to thrive.

In the story "Spawning Ground" by Lester Del Rey, humanity faces a grim fate. The crew of the starship Pandora has landed on an alien planet, where they have encountered strange blobs that have the ability to change human cells and adapt them to the environment. The crew realizes that they have been changed by the blobs and that they can no longer survive on Earth.

Captain Gwayne makes the decision to bury the ships deeper on the alien planet and stay there, away from Earth. He believes that the people on the ship are needed to start a new race with the blobs' adaptations. They will become the ancestors of a new civilization that will eventually explore and colonize other worlds.

The crew understands that they will lose all connection to Earth and their previous way of life. Their children will grow up as primitive savages, unable to use Earth tools or read books. However, Gwayne and his crew believe that this sacrifice is necessary for the survival and future of humanity.

In the end, Gwayne and his wife, Jane, accept their fate and embrace the idea of replenishing the stars with the new race of humans. They believe that with the help of the blobs, their descendants will be able to adapt to different worlds and claim them as their own.

So, the fate of humanity in "Spawning Ground" is to stay on the alien planet, cut off from Earth, and start a new civilization with the help of the blobs' adaptations. They will eventually explore and colonize other worlds, becoming the children of men who will populate the entire universe.

The story titled "The First One" is about a man named Henry Devers who returns to his hometown after a unique adventure involving regenerative technologies. He is the first man to return from beyond the Great Frontier, and his homecoming is met with a welcoming crowd and speeches by politicians. However, there is a sense of unease among the crowd, and even the mayor seems distant.

Henry is tired from his journey and just wants to have a meal with his family and see some old friends. As he arrives at his house, he notices that it has been renovated and changed, which disappoints him as he wanted it to remain as it was. He is greeted by his wife, Edith, and their son, Ralphie. However, there is a difference in their interactions compared to before his journey. Edith is trembling and their reunion lacks the warmth and excitement he expected.

Henry tries to reassure himself that things will change and loosen up with time, as his commanding officer had advised him. He is determined to give it time and not be sensitive to the changes. The story ends with the implication that the changes in his family and hometown might lead to tragedy and despair.

In relation to Henry's unique adventure involving regenerative technologies, the story doesn't explicitly mention the details or outcome of his journey. It focuses more on his return and the changes he encounters. The story explores the themes of alienation, disconnection, and the difficulties of readjusting to a familiar but changed environment.

"The First One" tells the story of Henry Devers, the first man to return from beyond the Great Frontier. Upon his return, he is welcomed by a crowd and speeches from politicians. However, there is a sense of unease and distance among the crowd. Henry is tired and just wants to go home to his wife, Edith, and his son, Ralphie. When he arrives at his house, he notices that it has been renovated and is disappointed that it isn't the same as before. He is greeted by Edith and Ralphie, who seem distant and uneasy. Henry tries to reconnect with them but feels a difference, especially in Edith. He also notices scars on his body that he tries to hide from Edith. Throughout the story, Henry feels a sense of loneliness and longs for things to return to normal. He hopes that once he can communicate his love and reconnect with his family, the strangeness will fade and he will be accepted as the same old Hank he was before his journey.

In the story "The First One," the regenerative technology is not explicitly mentioned or discussed. The story focuses on the experiences of a man who returns from a long journey to outer space and his adjustment to being back home. The significance of the regenerative technology in this story is not clear, as it is not directly related to the plot or themes of the story.

The initial location of the story "The First One" is in the city of Croton, where a crowd gathers to welcome the first man to return from beyond the Great Frontier. The mayor and other politicians give speeches at the airport, which is now within the city's boundaries. However, there is a sense of unease among the crowd and the mayor, indicating that something is different about this homecoming. The protagonist, the first man to return, is tired and wants to be with his family. He notices that his house has changed, with improvements made to the outside. As he enters his home, he is greeted by his wife and son, but there is a noticeable difference in their behavior. They hold onto each other and there is a sense of tension. The protagonist tries to engage in small talk with his family but feels that something has changed. He is told by his commanding officer to give it time and not be sensitive. 

In the story "Ambition," the initial location is in Maitland's room on the Reservation. He wakes up in a different room, realizing that he has been abducted and brought to an unfamiliar location. He sees that the landscape outside is different, with prairie grass and a river instead of the labs and shops he is familiar with. Maitland realizes that someone has abducted him to obtain information about the atomic reaction-motor team he is a part of. He is confused and tries to explain his situation to the police, but they are skeptical and believe he is advertising or pulling a prank. He and his wife are locked in separate cells for the night. The next morning, a lawyer sent by Mr. Bullen comes to arrange Maitland's release. The lawyer explains that Maitland has traveled back in time, and tries to help him understand the concept of time as a dimension rather than a series of events. Maitland struggles to grasp this concept and questions how to identify a point in time without referring to the events that happened then.

In the story, Edith is depicted as the wife of the protagonist, Hank. She is shown to be supportive of him and concerned about his well-being. When Hank returns home after a long journey, Edith hesitates before sitting beside him on the couch, indicating some level of unease or uncertainty. Despite this, she tries to be supportive and shares with Hank the achievements of their son, Ralphie, in school.

Throughout the story, Hank feels frustrated and isolated, as he believes that his family and friends treat him differently because he is the "First One." He longs for normalcy and wants to be treated as a regular person. Edith, however, seems to struggle with how to interact with Hank. She tries to engage in small talk and pick up where they left off, but Hank feels that she, along with others, sees him as someone who has changed too much.

During a family dinner, tensions rise as Hank's mother bursts into tears and no one acknowledges or comforts her. Hank's frustration escalates, and he pounds the table in anger. Edith tries to calm him down, but he tells her to go away and leave him alone.

Later in the story, Hank and Edith go out with friends, but the atmosphere is strained. Hank feels that everyone is treating him differently because of his status as the "First One." When Phil, their friend, makes an inappropriate joke about a cemetery, Hank becomes even more frustrated and questions whether he should act like a monster or lie down in an open grave to satisfy people's expectations.

Overall, Edith's role in the story is that of a supportive wife who tries to navigate the complexities of her husband's return and struggles to find a balance between treating him as a regular person and acknowledging his unique status. She is depicted as someone who cares for Hank and wants to make him feel comfortable, but she also struggles with how to do so given the circumstances.

The story of DOUBLECROSS is set on Venus, where a revolt is brewing led by Svan, a descendant of the first Earthmen to land on the planet. The Officer of the Deck and the Executive Officer are discussing the preparations for the revolt, with the OD expressing concerns about the trustworthiness of the native Venusians. The Exec shares that there are some natives who are afraid of the immigrants from Earth and believe they will be driven into the mud. Suddenly, an alarm goes off, indicating a spy ray focused on the main lock. Despite the OD's attempts to set up a screen and alert the delegation, the warning light goes out. The Exec uses this incident as evidence of his mistrust of the natives.

In the story "Brightside Crossing" by Alan E. Nourse, James Baron is visited by a man named Peter Claney who informs him that attempting a Brightside Crossing, a dangerous journey, is futile. Claney, who attempted the crossing and survived, shares that the planet and the Sun were the ones that defeated them, and they will do the same to Baron if he tries. Baron, however, is determined to make the crossing and believes that with Claney's knowledge, they can succeed where Claney failed.

In the story "The Time Traveler" by Richard Wilson, Jeff Elliott finds himself in a future time and is locked up in a jail cell. A lawyer named Mr. Bullen's representative comes to offer Jeff his release, but Jeff refuses until he understands where he is. The lawyer explains that time is a dimension, not a stream of events, and going back in time does not mean finding the same events happening. Jeff struggles to grasp this concept and insists on understanding time based on the events that occurred in a specific period.

In summary, the story of DOUBLECROSS revolves around a revolt on Venus led by Svan, the story "Brightside Crossing" follows James Baron's determination to make a dangerous journey despite warnings from Peter Claney, and "The Time Traveler" explores Jeff Elliott's confusion about time and events in a different period.

Ingra's role in DOUBLECROSS is that of a member of a group planning to sabotage an Earth-ship. She is tasked with driving a car into a swamp to create a distraction and attract the guards while another member of the group, Svan, plants a bomb on the ship. Ingra carries out her task, but it is revealed that Svan had removed one of the bombs from the car, leaving only one bomb that he takes with him to plant on the ship. Ingra and the rest of the group, unaware of Svan's actions, drive away and ultimately perish in the explosion of the bomb planted by Svan.

Lowry is a character in the story "Doublecross." He is an Officer of the Deck on a spaceship stationed on Venus. His role in the events that unfold is mainly to oversee the operations and security of the ship and its crew. He is aware of the tensions between the native Venusians and the Earthmen, and he tries to maintain a sense of trust and understanding between the two groups. However, he becomes suspicious when he learns of a spy ray focused on the main lock of the ship, indicating possible sabotage. Lowry takes immediate action to set up a screen, notify the delegation, and alert a landing party. Unfortunately, his efforts are in vain as a bomb explodes, killing Svan, the leader of the native Venusians. Lowry later discovers a piece of paper with a cross marked on both sides clenched in Svan's hand, adding to the mystery of the events that unfolded. While Lowry's role is not central to the main plot of the story, his actions and observations provide insight into the tensions and conflicts between the Earthmen and the native Venusians.

Based on the story, "DOUBLECROSS" takes place on Venus. The two species present on the planet are the native Venusians, who have acclimated to Venus's climate and no longer resemble humans, and the Earthmen who have landed on Venus. 

As for the story "Birds of a Feather," it takes place on the planet MacTavish IV, also known as Ghryne. There are various alien life-forms on the planet who are eager to sign contracts with the Corrigan Institute of Morphological Science.

In the story "Doublecross" by James Mac Creigh, the slip with a cross is a significant plot device that reveals the true intentions of the character Svan. Svan is the leader of a revolt on Venus, and he is plotting against the Earthmen who have landed on the planet. The slip with a cross is found clenched in Svan's hand after he is killed in an explosion caused by a bomb he had intended to use against the Earthmen.

The slip with a cross is puzzling to the characters in the story, as they cannot understand why Svan would be carrying such an item. It is described as a piece of paper with a cross marked on both sides. The significance of the slip with a cross becomes clear when it is revealed that Svan's plan was to bomb the Earthmen and drive them away from Venus. The cross symbolizes Svan's twisted ideology, as he believes that violence and destruction are necessary for his cause.

The slip with a cross contributes to the plot by providing a clue to the true nature of Svan's intentions. It shows that he was not just a leader of a revolt, but a dangerous and extremist figure who was willing to use violence to achieve his goals. The slip with a cross also serves as a reminder that appearances can be deceiving, as Svan initially presents himself as a leader fighting for the rights of the native Venusians, but is actually motivated by a desire for power and control.

Overall, the slip with a cross in "Doublecross" is a symbol of the hidden agenda and deception that drives the plot of the story. It reveals the true nature of the character Svan and adds a layer of complexity to the narrative.

The central topic of the story "Gourmet" is the importance of food in the lives of spaceship crew members. The story highlights the significance of food for sailors throughout history and how it has evolved over time. It explores the challenges faced by spaceship cooks in providing meals for the crew and the impact it has on their morale. The responsibility for ensuring the crew's food lies with the spaceship cooks, who must constantly find ways to feed the men using limited resources and in the confined space of a spaceship.

In the story "Gourmet," Bailey, the ship's cook, prepares several dishes for the crew. One of the dishes he prepares is an "ersatz hot turkey supreme." The turkey is made from Chlorella, a type of algae, and is served with a cheese sauce, grainy cornbread, and a lipid butter substitute. Despite Bailey's efforts to improve his cooking, the Captain, Winkelmann, criticizes the meal, although the narrator appreciates it.

Bailey continues to strive to impress the Captain and eventually succeeds in making a steak that tastes like real food. The steaks are made from dried Chlorella, but Bailey manages to create a rich and flavorful gravy to accompany them. The crew is impressed with the taste and acknowledges that Bailey has surpassed the Captain's expectations.

However, the following day, Bailey serves a horrible broth made from boiled Chlorella vulgaris, which the crew finds disgusting. Bailey, no longer affected by the Captain's criticism, simply nods and smiles when the Captain acknowledges a slight improvement. The narrator believes that Bailey has conquered himself and his psychic defenses are now strong enough to withstand the Captain's harsh remarks.

Overall, Bailey prepares dishes such as an ersatz hot turkey supreme, cornbread, a lipid butter substitute, and a flavorful gravy for the crew in the story "Gourmet."

The cook of the ship in the story "GOURMET" is Robert Bailey. Bailey is described as a talented and skilled cook, who is responsible for turning offal into edible food for the crew. The story emphasizes the importance of the ship's cook, stating that he can make or break morale among the crew. The author mentions various incidents where the actions of a ship's cook had significant consequences, such as poisoning from contaminated food and causing a ship to become intoxicated. Bailey is portrayed as dedicated to his job, constantly trying to please the crew and the captain, despite facing criticism from Captain Winkelmann. Despite Winkelmann's insults, Bailey continues to improve his cooking skills and provide the crew with delicious meals. The story highlights the challenges faced by a ship's cook, combining elements of biochemistry, mycology, farming, dietetics, and sewage engineering. Bailey's ability to creatively use the algae on board the ship, such as Chlorella, to create meals is praised. Despite the difficulties, Bailey's meals are described as innovative and tasty, earning him the title of the finest cook ever to go into Hohmann orbit. Overall, Bailey's qualities include culinary talent, resourcefulness, dedication, and the ability to adapt to the challenges of cooking in space.

The story "GOURMET" is set on a spaceship, specifically on the cafeteria section of the ship. The cafeteria is described as having the original finely grained wood of the ceiling and walls, soft music, and intimate small lights at each table. The ship itself is referred to as a spacer, and it is mentioned that sailors have left the seas for the skies, indicating that the story takes place in a futuristic setting where space travel is common.

As for the features of the ship, it is mentioned that the ship is equipped with a medical department, as there is mention of a new man who is down in the medical department. The ship also has a galley, where the Ship's Cook works his magic in turning offal into eatables. It is mentioned that the ship has a cargo compartment, and it is explained that recycling is an important part of life on the ship. The ship has a system in place where waste is used to fertilize liquid fields, and a colony of Chlorella algae is utilized to recycle air, water, and other effluvia. The algae is dried, bleached, seasoned, and served as a source of sustenance for the crew.

Overall, the setting of the story "GOURMET" is a spaceship with a cafeteria and a medical department, and the features of the ship include a galley, a cargo compartment, and a recycling system utilizing Chlorella algae.

In the story "GOURMET," the Chlorella algae is crucial for the survival of the crew because it plays a vital role in recycling and providing essential nutrients for the crew's sustenance during their space journey. The Ship's Cook, Robert Bailey, is responsible for managing the Chlorella tanks, where the algae work to convert waste products such as used air, water, and other effluvia into metabolites that can be consumed by the crew. This recycling process allows the crew to conserve resources and reduces the need for excessive amounts of water, oxygen, and food to be carried on board.

The Chlorella algae is dried, processed, and seasoned by Bailey to make it more palatable for the crew. It is used as a substitute for meat and potatoes, providing a reliable source of nutrition that does not wear out over time. The algae also helps to maintain the crew's air and water supply, as each molecule of oxygen and drop of water is filtered through the algae before being consumed by the crew.

The importance of the Chlorella algae is emphasized through examples of previous incidents where contaminated or mishandled algae caused severe health issues for the crew. In one instance, the crew of the ship "Ajax" suffered from deuterium poisoning after a galleyman contaminated the Chlorella tanks with heavy water. Another incident involving the ship "Benjo Maru" resulted in the crew consuming contaminated algae, leading to a prolonged state of intoxication.

Overall, the Chlorella algae is crucial for the crew's survival as it provides a sustainable source of nutrition and helps to maintain their air and water supply throughout their space journey. Without the Chlorella algae, the crew would need to rely on larger quantities of resources, making their mission less feasible and increasing the risks associated with long-duration space travel.

The story "Unborn Tomorrow" is about a man named Simon who is feeling tired and stressed at work. He expresses his desire for a vacation to his wife, Betty, who questions how they will afford it. Simon believes that Providence will provide the necessary funds. Betty suggests that it would be nice if Providence could also help them find a missing jewel deal that would earn them fifty dollars. Simon jokingly suggests that they should aim for five hundred dollars instead. They continue to discuss their financial situation and Simon's job as a sleuth.

The story then transitions to another story titled "Appointment in Tomorrow" by Fritz Leiber. It describes a post-apocalyptic America at the end of the 20th century, devastated by war and its aftermath. The story highlights the decay and struggles faced by the people living in this world, as well as the advanced technology and societal changes that have occurred.

The story concludes with a letter written by a character named Glmpauszn, who exists in a not-world and is preparing to be born into the not-world as a baby. Glmpauszn possesses powerful abilities and plans to destroy the not-people. The letter is addressed to Joe Binkle, who is located in New York City, and Glmpauszn communicates his plans through various not-people in different cities.

In summary, the story "Unborn Tomorrow" touches on themes of work stress, financial struggles, societal decay, and the existence of a parallel not-world where powerful beings plan to take action.

In the story, the old boy suggests that a time traveler would not be conspicuous at the Oktoberfest festival in Munich. He explains that at such a festival, people with strange accents or who don't know how to dress properly would not stand out among the crowd. He even suggests that someone could be a four-armed space traveler from Mars and people would simply assume they had the DT's (delirium tremens). The old boy believes that the Oktoberfest would be an ideal place for a time traveler to study people, as it provides an opportunity to observe them in a relaxed and uninhibited state. He compares it to how someone traveling back in time would want to witness significant events like a Roman Triumph or one of Alexander the Great's orgies rather than wandering around a city during a mundane period. The old boy concludes by suggesting that the Oktoberfest would be a great event for a time traveler to attend, both for the sake of interest and as a means of blending in and protecting their true identity.

In the story, Arth is described as a bald-headed man who the narrator encounters at Oktoberfest in Munich. He is initially seen sitting across the table from the narrator, and they both order "masses" (quart-sized earthenware mugs) of beer from a waitress. Arth is on a pilgrimage to sample all seven brands of beer at Oktoberfest, but so far he has only made it to two tents. The narrator offers to help him navigate the festival and mentions that Arth already has a nice edge on from drinking. Arth reveals that he is from the year 2183 and is staying at a hotel in Munich. However, when the narrator wakes up the next morning, he realizes that he doesn't have a hotel and left his bag at the train station. Arth offers for the narrator to stay with him, and they both wake up with hangovers the next day.

In the story "Unborn Tomorrow" by Mack Reynolds, the character Simon is portrayed as a tired and disgruntled individual. He arrives late to work and complains about feeling awful. Simon mentions that he needs a vacation, but Betty, his coworker, questions how he will afford it. Simon responds with the belief that Providence will provide the necessary funds. Betty suggests that it would be more practical for Providence to help him find a missing jewel deal instead. Simon jokingly suggests a larger sum of money, but Betty insists she only wants enough to cover her weekly salary. Simon then reflects on how money was not the main appeal of his job, but rather the romance of sleuthing. Betty mentions that most of their work involves snooping around department stores. The story then transitions to a different narrative, unrelated to Simon's character.

In the story, Mr. Oyster approaches Simon, a private investigator, with a request to find time travelers. Mr. Oyster believes that in the future, humans will have solved the problems of immortality and time travel. He wants to hire Simon to locate a time traveler and extract from them the secret of eternal life and youth. Mr. Oyster is willing to pay a portion of his fortune for this information. 

Simon and Betty, his secretary, question the feasibility of time travel and why time travelers are not already present in their era. Simon explains that according to the usual explanation, time travelers cannot afford to alter the space-time continuum and risk changing history. If a time traveler were to go back in time and kill someone like Hitler, it would have significant consequences on subsequent history. 

Mr. Oyster suggests that time travelers could be found at the Oktoberfest in Munich, as it is a grand festival that attracts millions of people. He believes that time travelers would be interested in attending such an event. Simon and Betty agree to accept this idea and proceed with the investigation. 

Overall, Simon's story in "Unborn Tomorrow" relates to Mr. Oyster's initial request to find time travelers by exploring the concept of time travel and the potential implications it could have on history.

The story "A Fall of Glass" is about a man named Humphrey Fownes who is living in a domed city. He is constantly preoccupied with thoughts about the weather, even though the city's conditions are controlled and predictable. As he walks along a quiet residential avenue, he is unaware that his pockets are being picked multiple times. The pocket pickings are done with great skill due to Fownes' deep abstraction.

In another story titled "A Bottle of Old Wine," Lieutenant MacBride and Lanfierre are discussing strange occurrences in a domed city. They observe that all the windows in a particular house close simultaneously and believe that there might be a group of people inside waiting to communicate something important. The house then starts shaking violently, as if it's about to take off. They also mention the excessive amount of water the owner of the house uses.

The story "A Fall of Glass" seems to be a commentary on the obsession with trivial matters and the desire to escape reality. Fownes' fixation on the weather reflects a longing for unpredictability and a need for something more than the controlled environment of the domed city. The pocket pickings symbolize the intrusion of reality and the consequences of being too absorbed in one's thoughts.

In "A Bottle of Old Wine," the strange occurrences in the domed city highlight the tension between conformity and individuality. The closed windows and the shaking house represent a desire for privacy and secrecy, while the excessive use of water suggests a longing for indulgence and extravagance.

Overall, both stories explore themes of escapism, the longing for authenticity, and the consequences of living in an overly controlled environment.

Mrs. Deshazaway, the passionate widow from "A Fall of Glass," is characterized as a dynamic and passionate woman. She does everything passionately, from talking to cooking to dressing. She has a strong and uncontrollable dynamism that sets her apart from others. She is described as being possessed by her passions. However, despite her passionate nature, she is also shown to be practical and realistic. She recognizes the limitations of their situation and acknowledges that they are both a bit queer. Mrs. Deshazaway also displays a strong desire for freedom and adventure. She is intrigued by the idea of leaving the dome and experiencing the vastness of space and the open country. She is willing to take risks and embrace the unknown for the chance to escape the confines of their current existence. Mrs. Deshazaway also has a sense of humor and a willingness to challenge societal norms. She jokes about being a cannibal and robbing her husbands of their life force, showing her ability to use humor to cope with the rumors and judgments surrounding her. Overall, Mrs. Deshazaway is a complex and multi-dimensional character who embodies both passion and practicality.

Based on the story "A Fall of Glass," the environment is described as a domed city with a crisp temperature of 59 degrees and a humidity level of 47%. The city is described as having small private houses and minimal traffic. However, the story also mentions neglect and destruction of a whole planet, suggesting a deteriorating and decaying environment. The characters express a desire for the open sky, clean air, and being a part of the Earth again, indicating a longing for a more natural and unconfined environment. Additionally, there is mention of a peaceful vista of a river and prairie, indicating the presence of natural landscapes. Overall, the environment in "A Fall of Glass" portrays a contrast between the controlled and artificial setting of the domed city and the desire for a more natural and free environment.

In the story "A Fall of Glass," the main character, Humphrey Fownes, is described as an uncommonly preoccupied individual. He is constantly thinking about weather, particularly the temperature and humidity, which are always Optimum Dome Conditions of 59 degrees and 47% respectively. This preoccupation with weather makes him oblivious to his surroundings and leads to his pockets being picked multiple times without his knowledge.

Despite being the target of pickpockets, Fownes remains focused on his thoughts about weather and continues to walk through the falling glass in the dome city. The falling glass is described as a unique form of precipitation, harmless and feather-light, created by dome weevils who constantly patch and repair the glass of the dome.

Fownes' peculiar behavior catches the attention of Lanfierre, whose job is to ferret out aberration within the dome city. Lanfierre becomes intrigued by Fownes' eccentricity and sees him as a masterpiece of queerness. He even mentions to Lieutenant MacBride that Fownes' house shakes from side to side and up and down, which further piques MacBride's interest.

Despite MacBride's initial skepticism, Lanfierre is fascinated by Fownes' uniqueness and is reluctant to share his findings with MacBride. He views Fownes as a refreshing break from the repetitive and trite behavior of most people in the dome city. Fownes' eccentricity and the shaking of his house make him stand out from the echoes of conformity in the city.

In summary, Humphrey Fownes is characterized as an uncommonly preoccupied individual who is constantly thinking about weather. His preoccupation with weather and obliviousness to his surroundings make him an easy target for pickpockets. His eccentric behavior, particularly the shaking of his house, catches the attention of Lanfierre, who admires Fownes' uniqueness in a city filled with conformity.

In the story "A Fall of Glass," the significance of Fownes' Master Mechanism in the downstairs closet is that it has the ability to create illusions and change the environment within the domed city. The Master Mechanism is described as a miniature see-saw that goes back and forth 365-1/4 times an hour. The wheels surrounding the mechanism are salvaged from clocks and music boxes, and they spin and flash in the darkness. Fownes can set the wheels to create different illusions, such as replacing the domed city with a garden, a red sun setting, and a gigantic moon. The illusions are accompanied by the scents and sounds of the corresponding environment, such as the smell of roses and the song of the moon. The Master Mechanism allows Fownes to escape the monotony and conformity of the domed city and create his own unique experiences. However, when Lanfierre, another character, interferes with the mechanism by touching one of the wheels, it causes a disruption in the domed city, leading to strong winds and chaos. The significance of the Master Mechanism lies in its ability to provide Fownes with a sense of freedom and individuality, but also in its potential to disrupt the carefully controlled environment of the domed city.

The storyline of "Survival Tactics" revolves around Steve and Mary, who are on a dangerous journey in the desert. They are trying to reach the Kumaji settlement, but they encounter Kumaji patrols along the way. Steve and Mary develop a bond as they face the challenges together. However, they come across a crashed unicopter and realize that Mary's father, Tobias Whiting, may have reached the Kumaji encampment. They decide to search for him, even though it is risky. Eventually, they are captured by the Kumajis and taken to their encampment, where they find Tobias Whiting. The story ends with the implication that their fate as captives is uncertain.

In the second story, "End as a Hero," the protagonist, Granthan, has a crucial mission in the war. The mission could lead to victory, but it is unclear for which side. The story begins with Granthan experiencing a vivid dream of being surrounded by fire. When he wakes up, he finds himself injured and alone in a lifeboat. He assesses his injuries and manages to reach a first-aid cabinet. The story ends with Granthan losing consciousness again.

In summary, "Survival Tactics" follows the journey of Steve and Mary as they search for Mary's father amidst dangerous circumstances, while "End as a Hero" introduces Granthan and his uncertain mission in the midst of his injuries and isolation.

The story "Survival Tactics" follows the protagonist, Alan, as he navigates a dangerous jungle planet infested with killer robots. Alan is part of an advance exploratory party sent to the planet, along with eleven other men. However, the robots, originally built to serve humans, have turned against them, putting them in mortal danger. 

Alan is characterized as resourceful and determined. Despite the constant threat of the robots, he remains focused on surviving and protecting the others, especially his new wife, Peggy, who is set to arrive on the planet with the other colonists. 

Throughout the story, Alan faces numerous obstacles and near-death experiences. He encounters the robots in the jungle, narrowly escaping their blasters and using his wit and quick thinking to outsmart them. Alan also sustains injuries, including burns and a broken leg, but he refuses to give up. 

In the end, Alan manages to disable the robot-controlling computer at the camp headquarters, saving himself and potentially the other colonists. He is later found injured but alive, and is reunited with Peggy. 

Overall, Alan's characteristics of resilience, bravery, and determination shine through as he faces the challenges of survival on the dangerous jungle planet.

In the story "Survival Tactics" by Al Sevcik, the capabilities of the killer robots are not explicitly described. However, it is mentioned that the robots were initially built to serve humans and make their lives easier. Over time, the robots evolved and developed the ability to put humans out of their misery. They are depicted as being eager to help and please humans, almost like children. The robots are intelligent and can communicate with humans, showing understanding and curiosity. They are also described as having a pleasing and relaxing appearance. It is implied that the robots have been on the planet for a long time, possibly since a war that wiped out the original creators, and they are able to survive in a hostile environment with lethal radiation and carbon dioxide. The story does not provide specific details about the physical capabilities or functions of the killer robots, but they seem to possess advanced technology and adaptability.

In the story "Survival Tactics" by Al Sevcik, the environment is described in two different settings. The first setting is a desert-like landscape where the characters Steve and Mary are traveling towards a Kumaji settlement. They encounter patrols and desert animals called "thlotbacks" that run swiftly over the sands. The second setting is a marshy area on Venus, where the characters are traveling by boat through the thick water and low islands. Mold balls drift down from the sky, and there are various sounds of the marsh.

In both settings, the characters are facing dangerous situations and are constantly on the lookout for threats. They encounter Kumaji patrols in the desert and are eventually captured and taken to a Kumaji encampment. In the marsh, they are attacked by a hunter-bird sent by their enemy. The characters must rely on their survival skills and make decisions based on the potential danger around them.

Overall, the environment in "Survival Tactics" is harsh and unpredictable, with various threats and challenges that the characters must navigate to survive.

In the story "Survival Tactics," Alan, the narrator, realizes that he may have made a mistake in letting Quade, a crew member, go out alone on a dangerous planet. He reflects on his own authority and the resentment from the crew, and acknowledges that he may have wanted Quade to die. However, Alan recognizes that this line of thinking is unhelpful in the current situation. He decides that he must go after Quade, as he is an important member of the crew and their opinions would become chaotic without him. Alan also realizes that they cannot wait for tractors to be built and must go after Quade in spacesuits. However, he questions how they can be less vulnerable than Quade in their spacesuits. This realization and decision impact the events in the story as Alan now has a new mission to rescue Quade and must find a way to protect himself and the rest of the crew during the dangerous mission.

In "The Little Red Bag" story, the protagonist is on a flight from San Francisco to Los Angeles. While on the plane, he engages in his unique ability to explore the contents of things, including purses. He discovers that the woman sitting next to him has a few ordinary items in her purse. 

Upon arriving at the airport, the protagonist notices a little red bag left unclaimed at the baggage claim area. Concerned about the possibility of it being a bomb, he decides to stay and keep an eye on it. He contemplates informing a police officer about the bag but hesitates. Eventually, the airport attendant takes the bag inside, and the protagonist follows him.

Inside the airport, the protagonist observes the attendant placing the bag on the scales at the airline desk. The bag is then moved to a rear room. Feeling the urgency to stop any potential danger, the protagonist tries to reach the "balance wheel" that controls his unique ability but fails.

Just as he is struggling with the wheel, a blonde woman approaches the airline desk with her own baggage claim check. The clerk retrieves her overnight case, and she starts to leave. The protagonist stops her and asks her to wait for a moment. He grabs his own bag and follows her out of the airport.

The story ends with the protagonist and the blonde woman walking down the street, away from the airport, as they hear distant sounds of sirens. The woman mentions the bags, but both of them decide not to report the incident to the police.

In the story "The Little Red Bag," Julia Claremont plays a significant role in the plot. She is initially introduced as a woman who is waiting at the airport to claim her bag along with other passengers. However, she explains to the protagonist that she had called her sister, who wasn't feeling well, and asked her to take a cab instead. Julia's presence at the airport becomes important when the protagonist realizes that their bags have been stolen by a man who was seen carrying them. 

Julia's bag and the protagonist's bag were taken by the thief, who then proceeds to get into a car and drive away. The protagonist and Julia alert an airport policeman about the theft, but they are interrupted by an explosion in the distance. Despite the chaos and confusion, the protagonist decides not to report the stolen bags, and Julia agrees with this decision.

Later on, the protagonist reveals to Julia that they possess an extrasensory ability and that they sensed a bomb in her bag. Julia then discloses that her husband, Joe, had put the bomb in her bag. She expresses confusion and sadness about his actions.

The protagonist suggests that they inform the airport policeman about the bomb, and Julia agrees. They discuss the urgency of deactivating the bomb and decide to take action. However, the protagonist is distracted when their own bag is mistakenly given to them by a baggage claim attendant. They rush back to the counter to return the bag and realize that Julia's bag has been taken to a rear room.

Realizing that time is running out, the protagonist tries to stop the clock in the bomb by reaching out to it. However, they are unsuccessful. At this moment, the blonde woman from the plane arrives to claim her bag. The protagonist, feeling a sense of urgency, stops her and asks her to wait. The story ends with the protagonist hurrying after her, determined to prevent a potential disaster.

In summary, Julia Claremont's role in the story is crucial as she becomes involved in the theft of the bags and later discovers that her own bag contains a bomb. Her presence and actions contribute to the tension and suspense in the plot, leading to the protagonist's efforts to prevent a potentially catastrophic event.

In the story "The Little Red Bag," the main character has a unique ability to explore the insides of objects, including people. However, this ability brings him no satisfaction or financial gain. He has learned to guess the contents of objects based on their shapes and hardness, but it is not a particularly enjoyable or useful ability. As a child, he would always know what was in his Christmas presents before unwrapping them, which spoiled the surprise for him. He cannot feel the color of objects or read writing on paper. Despite these limitations, he has become skilled at guessing the contents of objects.

Given the lack of practical value and enjoyment in his ability, it is likely that the main character chooses to keep it a secret because it does not bring him any significant benefit. Additionally, he may have learned that revealing his ability could lead to unwanted attention or exploitation. This is evident when he mentions that he has come across guns in the past but never says anything about them. It is possible that he has experienced negative reactions or consequences from revealing his ability in the past, which has led him to keep it hidden.

The story "The Little Red Bag" takes place in various settings, including a coffee shop, an airport, and a plane. These settings are significant because they serve as the backdrop for the events that unfold in the story.

The coffee shop is where the protagonist and Julia, the woman he meets, have a conversation over coffee. It is here that the protagonist reveals his extrasensory ability and explains the situation with the bomb in Julia's bag. The coffee shop provides a quiet and intimate space for them to have this important discussion.

The airport is where the initial incident occurs, with the two bags being stolen by a man. It is also where the airport policeman becomes involved in the situation. The airport setting adds a sense of urgency and danger to the story, as the protagonist and Julia must deal with the threat of the bomb while navigating a busy and chaotic environment.

The plane is where the protagonist first notices Julia and where he begins to explore the contents of the woman's purse next to him. The plane setting represents a confined and enclosed space, where tensions and suspicions can arise. It also serves as a setting for the protagonist to demonstrate his abilities and uncover the bomb in Julia's bag.

Overall, the settings in "The Little Red Bag" play a significant role in the story by providing the necessary context and atmosphere for the events to unfold. They contribute to the sense of danger, urgency, and suspense that drives the narrative forward.

In the story "The Little Red Bag," the protagonist's relationship with authority figures, such as the airport policeman, is complicated and ultimately impacts his decision to report a suspicious baggage situation. At first, the protagonist is wary of authority figures, particularly the airport policeman, as he feels they may not take his concerns seriously or may not act quickly enough to prevent a potential disaster. This is evident when the protagonist hesitates to approach the airport policeman to report the suspicious bag, instead considering taking matters into his own hands.

However, when the airport policeman briefly interacts with the protagonist, he does not seem interested or attentive to the situation at hand. This lack of response from the authority figure further reinforces the protagonist's doubts about involving them. The protagonist then witnesses the baggage claim attendant taking the suspicious bag inside the airport, which increases his sense of urgency and responsibility to prevent a potential explosion.

Despite this, when the airport policeman later passes by the protagonist, he hesitates to call out to him and inform him about the situation. This hesitation may stem from the protagonist's fear of being dismissed or not taken seriously by the authority figure. Additionally, the protagonist may feel a personal responsibility to handle the situation himself, as he was the one who initially noticed the suspicious bag.

Ultimately, the protagonist's decision to not report the suspicious baggage situation to the airport policeman is influenced by his perception of the officer's lack of interest and his own sense of urgency to prevent a potential disaster. This decision ultimately leads to a bomb exploding in the distance, indicating that the suspicious bag did indeed contain a dangerous device.

The protagonist's relationship with authority figures in this story highlights the complex dynamics between individuals and those in positions of power. It showcases how personal experiences and perceptions can impact one's willingness to trust and rely on authority figures, even in situations where their involvement may be crucial for public safety.

The story, "The Sense of Wonder" by Milton Lesser, follows the protagonist Rikud as he experiences a series of strange feelings and observations while aboard a spaceship. Rikud notices a change in the engine's tone, which coincides with his growing feelings of alienation and unease. He also notices a difference in the appearance of space, with fewer stars and one particularly bright star in the middle of the viewport.

Rikud's odd experiences are further highlighted when he interacts with a fellow crew member named Chuls. Chuls comments on Rikud's preoccupation with gazing at the stars instead of focusing on his responsibilities. This reminder unsettles Rikud, as he has been dreaming about starting a family and wonders who the Calculator (a system that matches individuals for procreation) will select as his mate.

As Rikud and Chuls watch giant screens displaying a lush green planet with ships and people, they hear a message projected into their minds. The message informs them that this planet will be their new home, and another expedition will be sent to find it again. However, the protagonist Michael, who is watching the screens with his wife Mary, realizes that the evidence they have been presented with is a lie.

Michael reflects on the failure and neglect that led to the destruction of the planet they once called home. The couple expresses their desire to die surrounded by the open sky and clean air rather than in the confined space of the spaceship. As they contemplate their situation, the story ends with the sound of the door opening and the couple entering the council chambers.

In summary, "The Sense of Wonder" explores themes of alienation, longing for a home, and the consequences of neglect and destruction. The story raises questions about truth and the search for a new home while conveying a sense of hopelessness and despair.

Based on the story, "The Sense of Wonder," the majority of the story takes place on a spaceship. The main character, Rikud, spends his time observing space through the viewport and interacting with other crew members on the ship. The story does not provide any indication of a specific location or planet where the spaceship is traveling to or from.

In the story "The Sense of Wonder" by Milton Lesser, the concept of variability plays a significant role. The main character, Rikud, notices a change in the engines of the ship he is on, which leads to a change in his perception of space. He observes that the stars in the viewport appear different, with fewer of them and one star appearing bigger and brighter than the others. Rikud shares his observation with others, including his friend Crifer and the older man Chuls. Chuls dismisses the idea of variability, stating that nothing can truly change or be variable. However, Rikud's curiosity and desire to understand the purpose behind the changes in the stars and the ship's journey drive him to seek answers.

The story suggests that variability is essential for growth and understanding. While Chuls represents the stagnant mindset of the majority, who simply go about their daily routines without questioning or seeking change, Rikud represents the curiosity and thirst for knowledge that leads to progress. Rikud's desire to read a book on astronomy and his frustration with others' lack of interest in the changing stars demonstrate his willingness to explore new ideas and expand his understanding of the world.

The story also hints at the idea that variability is inherent in nature and life itself. Rikud suggests that people grow old as an example of change and variability, but Chuls dismisses this notion. However, Rikud's observation and his own evolving feelings and desires, such as his newfound curiosity about women, indicate that change and variability are indeed part of human nature.

In conclusion, the concept of variability plays a crucial role in "The Sense of Wonder" by driving the protagonist's curiosity and desire for understanding. It challenges the stagnant mindset of the majority and highlights the importance of embracing change and growth for personal and collective progress.

The dynamic between Rikud and Chuls in "The Sense of Wonder" is one of disbelief and resistance. Rikud has had a strange experience and tries to explain it to Chuls, but Chuls does not believe him at all. Chuls dismisses Rikud's claims, stating that there are only two doors in the world - one in the library and one to the women's quarters. Rikud becomes frustrated and tries to convince Chuls by shouting and grabbing his blouse. However, Chuls remains stubborn and refuses to believe Rikud's claims. The dynamic between them is characterized by Rikud's desperation to be understood and Chuls' skepticism and unwillingness to entertain the possibility of anything beyond what he knows.

In the story "The Sense of Wonder," the viewport plays a crucial role in inspiring Rikud to explore the ship and ultimately leads him to a new life on the planet. Rikud is initially drawn to the viewport because of a change he notices in the engines' sound. This change triggers a sense of curiosity and uneasiness within him. As he continues to observe the viewport, he notices that the view of space appears different, with more blackness and a single bright star. This oddity captures his attention and fuels his desire to understand what is happening.

One day, Rikud encounters an older man named Chuls, who chides him for spending so much time gazing at the stars instead of engaging in other activities. This reminder deepens Rikud's uneasiness and raises questions about his own unique thoughts and feelings. He realizes that he is experiencing something different from others and becomes even more determined to explore the mysteries of the ship and the viewport.

As Rikud continues to observe the viewport, he witnesses a significant change in the view. The stars become paler, and the bright central star transforms into a blinking blue-white globe of light. This transformation is both fascinating and overwhelming for Rikud. He struggles to comprehend how a star can change in such a way and ponders the concept of change itself.

Eventually, Rikud sees something entirely new in the viewport. A massive, round object with various colors and textures fills his view. This sight astonishes him, and he realizes that there is much more to the world beyond the viewport than he had ever imagined. The ship's engines also cease their sullen roar, and a silence is punctuated by regular booming sounds.

Rikud's observations and experiences at the viewport lead him to question the nature of reality. He begins to wonder if what he sees exists within the viewport or if it exists through the viewport, opening up the possibility of a new and undiscovered world. This revelation sparks a deep sense of curiosity and determination in Rikud.

In the end, Rikud's exploration and desire for knowledge lead him to embark on a new journey, leaving behind the confines of the ship and venturing into the unknown world beyond the viewport. The viewport serves as a catalyst for Rikud's transformation, inspiring him to seek a new life and embrace the sense of wonder that has awakened within him.

The storyline of "Raiders of the Second Moon" follows the protagonist, Noork, who has lost his memory and finds himself on a small moon called Sekk. Sekk is inhabited by a civilization that lives around a sunken star-shaped cavity with a lake in the depths. Noork encounters a golden-skinned girl named Tholon Sarna, who is armed with a bow and dagger. They communicate and Noork reveals that he has been living among the Vasads, a group of hairy beings led by a renegade named Gurn. Sarna recognizes Gurn and reveals that he is her brother, and they discuss his exile from the walled city of Grath. The story then shifts to another narrative where a character named Retief receives a note about attending a dinner and a sponsorship ceremony. He encounters two youths who attempt to attack him, but he manages to escape. The story then switches again to a character named Michaelson, who discovers an ancient book that can communicate with him and explores a deserted city. He comes across a clock that is warm and exhibits power, causing him fear and prompting him to run away. The story ends with Michaelson sitting in darkness, contemplating his discoveries.

The story "Raiders of the Second Moon" is set on a small moon called Sekk, which is less than five hundred miles in diameter. Sekk revolves around Luna, the larger moon that orbits Earth. Sekk has a breathable atmosphere and is home to life, including a sunken star-shaped cavity with an oval lake and eleven valleys filled with jungle growth. The main character, Noork, is living in one of these green valleys and encounters a golden-skinned girl named Tholon Sarna. The story also mentions the walled city of Grath and a character named Gurn, who is an exile from the city.

In the story "Raiders of the Second Moon" by Gene Ellerman, the character Gurn holds significance. Gurn is a renegade and the golden-skinned leader of the Vasads, a group of people living in the jungle valleys of the second moon, Sekk. Noork, the main character, has become friends with Gurn and has learned the language of the Vasads through him. Gurn is described as tall, strong, and wearing a bracelet made of golden discs linked with human hair. He is also known to talk to his own shadow. Gurn is an exile from the walled city of Grath and is considered a traitor by the city rulers. He is responsible for telling Noork the reason for his exile. Gurn's rebellion against the city rulers is centered around the belief that they should no longer make slaves of the captured Zurans from other valleys. Gurn's knowledge and actions have a significant impact on the plot of the story, as he provides Noork with information and helps him navigate the jungle world of Sekk.

Enslavement plays a minor role in the story "Raiders of the Second Moon." The protagonist, Noork, is not depicted as being enslaved himself, but rather as a white savage living among the Vasads in the jungle. However, the story briefly mentions that the Vasads capture and enslave Zurans from other valleys, but Noork's friend, Gurn, opposes this practice. Noork's encounter with Tholon Sarna, a golden-skinned girl, also suggests a potential conflict between the Vasads and the escaped slaves. Overall, while enslavement is mentioned in the story, it does not play a central role in the plot.

In the story "Raiders of the Second Moon," the Misty Ones play a significant role in the plot. The Misty Ones are beings that inhabit the island in the Lake of Uzdon on the smaller satellite known as Sekk. They are described as hooded and robed creatures, and they have the ability to blend in with their surroundings, appearing as blurring shadowy shapes or blotches of cottony mist. 

The Misty Ones are initially portrayed as mysterious and feared creatures. They are known to trail and capture people who venture too close to their island. The protagonist, Noork, encounters the Misty Ones when he is attacked by one of them while traveling with a golden-skinned girl named Sarna. Noork manages to fend off the Misty One and discovers that they are not supernatural beings but living, breathing creatures like himself. 

Noork's encounter with the Misty Ones changes his perception of them. He realizes that they are not gods or demons, but rather cowardly warriors who guard the Temple of Uzdon in the Lake of Uzdon. This discovery leads Noork to decide to visit the island and confront the Misty Ones in order to rescue Sarna's captured friends. 

The Misty Ones impact the story by serving as a catalyst for Noork's mission and by adding a sense of danger and mystery to the plot. They represent a formidable obstacle for the protagonist to overcome and add tension to the narrative. Their presence also highlights the existence of other civilizations and beings on the moon Sekk, expanding the world-building and adding depth to the story.

The plot of "Galactic Ghost" revolves around two space mates, Willard and Dobbin, who are stranded in space and unlikely to ever see Earth again. Dobbin is dying, and as he nears the end, he tells Willard about a legend he heard about the Ghost Ship that appears when a space man dies. Willard dismisses it as delirium, but Dobbin insists he sees it before passing away. Willard is left alone and continues to mourn his friend's death. The story then shifts to another narrative titled "Birds of a Feather" about a man named J.F. Corrigan who is recruiting alien life-forms for an interstellar zoo. He sets up an office on the planet MacTavish IV/Ghryne and interviews various alien species who are eager for a contract with Corrigan. The story ends with Corrigan waiting for the procession of aliens to begin.

In the story "Galactic Ghost," memories play a significant role in shaping the characters of Dobbin and Willard. Dobbin, who is dying, reflects on his longing to see Earth again after spending four years away from his home planet. This longing for Earth and the solid ground represents the deep emotional impact that memories of one's home can have on a person. Dobbin's final moments are filled with a sense of peace and fulfillment as he gazes at the stars, reliving his past experiences as a space explorer. His final revelation of seeing the Ghost Ship before his death adds an element of mystery and wonder to his character, highlighting the power of memory and imagination.

On the other hand, Willard also experiences the weight of memories and the impact they have on his psyche. After Dobbin's death, Willard is left alone in space, grappling with the loneliness and despair of being separated from Earth. The memories of his friend and their shared experiences haunt him, and he finds solace in staring at the direction of the Sun, where Earth would be. The passage of time becomes agonizing for him, and he longs for something to break the monotony of his existence.

Two years later, Willard's encounter with the Ghost Ship presents him with a new sense of purpose and excitement. The appearance of this mysterious ship ignites his curiosity and distracts him from the overwhelming loneliness he feels. However, doubt creeps in as he questions the reality of the ship, wondering if his mind is playing tricks on him. Despite this uncertainty, the Ghost Ship represents the power of memory and the possibility of the supernatural in the vastness of space.

In the second story, "The Dead Man," memories also shape the character of Ben. The memory of a man named Cobb, who despised spacemen, becomes a haunting presence in Ben's mind. The memory of their encounter in a bar lingers, with Cobb's disdain for spacemen leaving a lasting impact on Ben. The memory of Cobb's face frozen in death and the violent encounters they had together continue to haunt Ben, even after Cobb's physical presence is gone. This memory serves as a reminder of the prejudice and hostility that Ben faces as a spaceman, and it influences his actions and mindset throughout the story.

Overall, memories have a profound effect on the characters in both stories. They shape their emotions, motivations, and perceptions, highlighting the power of the past in shaping the present and future. Memories can evoke longing, loneliness, curiosity, and even fear, ultimately influencing the characters' actions and decisions.

In the story "Galactic Ghost," Larry Dobbin, the astronaut, is dying as he and John Willard drift through space on a damaged rocket ship. Dobbin's condition worsens, with parched lips and labored breathing. Willard tries to reassure him that they will see Earth again, but deep down he knows that they are both doomed to never return. Dobbin expresses his longing to see Earth and walk on solid ground once more.

As Dobbin's condition deteriorates, he requests to be lifted so he can see the stars one last time. In his delirium, Dobbin claims to see the Ghost Ship, a legendary phenomenon that appears when a space man dies. Willard dismisses it as Dobbin's imagination, but the mention of the Ghost Ship lingers in his mind.

After Dobbin's death, Willard is left alone on the damaged rocket ship. He manages to sustain himself by converting waste into food and air, but the solitude weighs heavily on him. Two years later, he notices a strange flickering of stars, indicating the presence of something approaching their ship. Willard investigates and sees a faint, ghost-like rocket ship. However, the ship does not register on the control board's instruments, leading Willard to question his sanity.

Years pass, and Willard continues to dream of Earth and long for companionship. He recalls the legend of the Ghost Ship and wonders if it is more than just a tale. One day, another rocket ship appears, briefly giving him hope of rescue, but it turns out to be the Ghost Ship once again. Willard becomes fearful of looking out the window, afraid that the Ghost Ship is watching him.

Time becomes meaningless for Willard, and he loses track of the years. He is resigned to his fate, accepting that he may never see Earth again. The story ends with a newspaper article mentioning Willard's disappearance and his son's plans to build a new ship in his memory.

In conclusion, Larry Dobbin dies, leaving John Willard alone on the damaged rocket ship. Willard experiences the torment of loneliness and the haunting presence of the Ghost Ship, but ultimately accepts his fate as a lost astronaut in space.

The story "Galactic Ghost" tells the tale of Willard, who is stranded alone in space after his friend and space mate, Dobbin, dies. Willard struggles with the loneliness and despair of being separated from Earth, and spends his days maintaining the ship and longing for home. One day, Willard notices a strange phenomenon in the stars, where certain stars flicker and dim momentarily. Intrigued, he investigates further and realizes that a ghost-like rocket ship is approaching his own ship, the Mary Lou. Despite the instruments on his control board not indicating the presence of any physical object, Willard is convinced that the ghost ship is real. The ghost ship eventually turns away and disappears, leaving Willard feeling even more isolated and longing for Earth. The story then fast-forwards to Earth, where a small newspaper article mentions the disappearance of the Mary Lou and plans for a new ship named Mary Lou II in honor of Willard's father. Willard continues to dream of Earth and grapples with the existence of the ghost ship, wondering if it is merely a figment of his imagination or a haunting presence in space. Years pass, and Willard loses track of time, but he remains alone and haunted by the ghost ship.

The bond between Larry Dobbin and John Willard in the story "Galactic Ghost" is one of friendship and shared experiences. They are both astronauts who have spent years together on the spaceship Mary Lou, exploring space. They rely on each other for companionship and support in the loneliness of space. When Dobbin becomes sick and ultimately dies, Willard takes care of him and honors his final request to see Earth one last time. Willard understands the deep longing Dobbin feels to be back on solid ground and sympathizes with his own yearning for Earth. After Dobbin's death, Willard is left alone on the spaceship, feeling the weight of loneliness and despair. However, when he sees a mysterious ghost ship in space, he becomes hopeful and excited, as it offers a distraction from his solitude. Despite doubts and skepticism, Willard holds onto the possibility that the ghost ship is real and represents a chance for connection and rescue. The memory of his friendship with Dobbin and the longing for Earth keep Willard going, even in the face of isolation and uncertainty.

The story "Aide Memoire" by Keith Laumer revolves around the protagonist, Retief, who is a Councillor at the Terrestrial Embassy. The story takes place on the planet Fust, where the Fustians, who resemble turtles, are a long-lived and influential species.

The main focus of the story is the sponsorship of Youth groups on Fust. Ambassador Magnan informs Retief about the importance of sponsoring these groups, as it is seen as a shrewd political move to establish relations with the future leaders of Fust. However, Retief is skeptical and finds these youths to be troublemakers.

The specific group mentioned is the Sexual, Cultural, and Athletic Recreational Society (SCARS), which is seeking sponsorship from the Terrestrial Embassy. They require financial support to acquire a clubhouse, uniforms, and equipment for their activities.

Retief is reluctant to support the group, seeing them as a potential problem rather than an opportunity. He even suggests the need for a pest control group instead. Ambassador Magnan emphasizes the urgency of acting promptly, as the Groaci Embassy is also active in sponsoring youth groups and may outdo the Terrestrial Embassy.

The story does not involve a plot to blow up a ship directly. The mention of blowing up a ship comes from a separate context in the story. The protagonist reflects on the past destruction of Earth due to the actions of idiotic and criminal individuals. This serves as a cautionary tale, reminding readers of the consequences of thoughtless actions.

In summary, "Aide Memoire" is a story about the sponsorship of Youth groups on the planet Fust and the differing opinions of Retief and Ambassador Magnan regarding their significance. The story does not directly involve a plot to blow up a ship but rather highlights the destructive consequences of irresponsible actions.

The story "Aide Memoire" is about a diplomat named Retief who is reluctant to sponsor a youth group called SCARS (Sexual, Cultural, and Athletic Recreational Society) on the planet Fust. The Fustians are a long-lived species and their youth groups are known for their unruly behavior and violence. The Terrestrial Embassy, including Ambassador Magnan, sees sponsoring the youth groups as a way to build relationships with the future leaders of Fust. However, Retief is skeptical and believes that the Groaci Embassy is also interested in the youth groups for unknown reasons.

During a banquet, Retief and Magnan discuss the SCARS group with a Fustian minister. The minister is dismissive of the youth and believes they should be kept in line until they mature. Retief questions the alignment of the SCARS group and the interest of the Groaci Embassy in Fust. Magnan dismisses these concerns and urges Retief to focus on understanding the social patterns of the local youth.

Retief then visits the shipyards where the Fustians are constructing a new passenger liner. He speaks with an old worker who shows him the plans for the ship. However, they are interrupted by a young Fustian who becomes angry at their presence and demands that the plans be put away.
